title: New Start Time
question_text: A school is pondering starting the school day earlier. The assistant principal comes up with a survey to ask students if they support the change to an earlier time. She then waits at the school entrance and asks the first $30$ students who show up to school. Should the school trust the results of the survey?

choices.text: No, because the first students to the school will not be affected by an earlier start time.
No, because the assistant principal did a survey and not an experiment.
Yes, because she asked a sample of students.
Yes, because a random sample is not necessary.

solution:
The assistant principal is collecting data regarding the new school start time. She asks 30 30 students their thoughts on the new schedule for a survey.

The issue that the assistant principal has is that she asks the first 30 30 students. This does not represent a random sample, and given that variation may or may not be random, the conclusions are uncertain. These students would be the most likely to not be affected by a schedule change.

Choice 'A' is correct.
